results.title: Elliptical orbits
results.creator_credit: Norton Bloom, Kevin Smith and Educational Services
results.brief_description: Starting with an elliptic orbit (as of a satellite) and using Kepler’s law of areas, shows that the gravitational force on the satellite obeys an inverse square relation. The derivation is almost entirely geometric in nature.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Norton Bloom, Kevin Smith and Educational Services

results.title: Elizabethan stage: Henry V [study extract]
results.brief_description: The opening sequence of Olivier’s film version of “Henry V”. A remarkable recreation of Shakespeare’s London, showing the first part of the play as it may well have been produced originally on the stage of the Globe Theatre. Olivier’s treatment has been very free, and many amusing sidelights on the actors and audiences of Shakespeare’s day are included. Cast includes Laurence Olivier, Robert Helpmann, Leslie Banks, Quentin Crisp.

results.title: Elizabethan express
results.creator_credit: Tony Thompson, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: From King’s Cross Station, London, to Waverley Station, Edinburgh, is 393 miles. The Elizabethan - a summertime express - does this journey in six and a half hours non-stop - the longest daily non-stop run in the world to be timed at over 60 mph in 1954. This film is about one of those runs and the people behind the service.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Tony Thompson, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: Elephants
results.brief_description: The setting of this film is a farm where elephants are trained as circus performers. The animals are shown eating, bathing and doing their tricks.

results.title: The Elephant will never forget
results.brief_description: Trams in London are a thing of the past - buses have taken over. The film, completed in London’s “Last Tram Week”, takes you round the streets of South London and along the embankment with 2 cockneys who remember a song about trams that they sang in the music halls fifty years ago. Finally, 20,000 Londoners cheer and sing their goodbyes to the trams which for 91 years have rattled and clanged and swayed by.

results.title: Elephant boy
results.creator_credit: Robert Joseph Flaherty, Zoltan Korda, Alexander Korda and London Film Productions
results.brief_description: Based on Kipling”s “Toomai of the Elephants”, with Sabu as little Toomai, son of the Mahout, and Kala Nag, the elephant. Tells the story of a government expedition in search of wild elephants in the state of Mysore. Toomai’s adventures with Kala Nag and the herd of wild elephants finally leads him to be accorded with the same title of his famous grandfather “Toomai of the Elephants”. This film was beset with difficulties from the start. After years of attempting to obtain sufficient finance to film Kipling’s original story, Flaherty found support from Alexander Korda in 1935 and the Flahertys journeyed to India to adopt (from them) a new method of film making - the original practice adopted by Flaherty of “letting the story flow” and absorbing the way of life of native people and their surroundings was not entirely carried out in the case of “Elephant boy”. Whilst much of the film was shot in studios in England, the film is distinguished by beautiful photography and many fine sequences breathing the very atmosphere of India, captured by Flaherty on location

results.creator_credit: Morris Meisner and ERPI Classroom Films

results.title: Application of Pascal's Law. Part 1. The Hydraulic jack
results.creator_credit: United States. Navy. Bureau of Aeronautics
results.brief_description: The film reviews Pascal’s Law, and studies the input and output pistons and the system in actual motion. Demonstrates how work is done by means of a hydraulic system and how the amount of work performed is measured.
